values.description: Homebrew recently switched to python3, which required some [updates to release-tools](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/release-tools/pull-requests/541). While testing those changes in release-tools, I found that all the gazebo GUI tests were being marked as failures ([here for example](https://build.osrfoundation.org/job/gazebo-ci-pr_any-homebrew-amd64/1426/testReport/)), and I traced it down to a problem with check_test_ran.py. We should merge this forward and port the change to any repositories that use QTests.
values.title: Support python3 with check_test_ran.py

summary.raw: Homebrew recently switched to python3, which required some [updates to release-tools](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/release-tools/pull-requests/541). While testing those changes in release-tools, I found that all the gazebo GUI tests were being marked as failures ([here for example](https://build.osrfoundation.org/job/gazebo-ci-pr_any-homebrew-amd64/1426/testReport/)), and I traced it down to a problem with check_test_ran.py. We should merge this forward and port the change to any repositories that use QTests.
summary.html: Homebrew recently switched to python3, which required some updates to release-tools. While testing those changes in release-tools, I found that all the gazebo GUI tests were being marked as failures (here for example), and I traced it down to a problem with check_test_ran.py. We should merge this forward and port the change to any repositories that use QTests.

values.description: This fixes some undefined behavior in the `ODESliderJoint` class caused by neglecting to initialize some data. Since this is undefined behavior, it will nondeterministically result in very problematic behavior whenever any part of the code tries to use the result of `ODESliderJoint::GetAnchor()`. In particular, calling `Joint::SetPosition(~)` on a slider joint may cause the simulation to explode, even when `SetPosition(~)` is only being used during initialization. Specifically, [`Joint::ComputeChildLinkPose(~)`](#!/osrf/gazebo/src/bedaf66d30341070c8f44c9be09d8877c57f2e67/gazebo/physics/Joint.cc?at=gazebo7&fileviewer=file-view-default#Joint.cc-1407) will output a bad transform whenever we get unlucky with the undefined behavior.
values.title: Fix undefined behavior in ODESliderJoint

summary.raw: This fixes some undefined behavior in the `ODESliderJoint` class caused by neglecting to initialize some data. Since this is undefined behavior, it will nondeterministically result in very problematic behavior whenever any part of the code tries to use the result of `ODESliderJoint::GetAnchor()`. In particular, calling `Joint::SetPosition(~)` on a slider joint may cause the simulation to explode, even when `SetPosition(~)` is only being used during initialization. Specifically, [`Joint::ComputeChildLinkPose(~)`](#!/osrf/gazebo/src/bedaf66d30341070c8f44c9be09d8877c57f2e67/gazebo/physics/Joint.cc?at=gazebo7&fileviewer=file-view-default#Joint.cc-1407) will output a bad transform whenever we get unlucky with the undefined behavior.
summary.html: This fixes some undefined behavior in the ODESliderJoint class caused by neglecting to initialize some data. Since this is undefined behavior, it will nondeterministically result in very problematic behavior whenever any part of the code tries to use the result of ODESliderJoint::GetAnchor(). In particular, calling Joint::SetPosition(~) on a slider joint may cause the simulation to explode, even when SetPosition(~) is only being used during initialization. Specifically, Joint::ComputeChildLinkPose(~) will output a bad transform whenever we get unlucky with the undefined behavior.

values.description:
This pull request adds a new command to gz topic to send requests.

Its prototype is: `gz topic -r <request_name>  [-m <message>] [-f <file>]`

Optional data can be sent with options -m or -f where message is a message to send and file is the path to a file containing the message to send.

Some command line examples:

    $ gz topic -r atmosphere_info
    
    type: ADIABATIC
    temperature: 288.15
    pressure: 101325
    mass_density: 1.2249782197913108
    enable_atmosphere: true
    
    $ gz topic -r entity_delete -m ground_plane
    $ gz topic -r unknown_request
    No response received

Note that this pull request also adds a timeout parameter to gazebo::transport::request whose default value is -1 to wait forever.
values.title: Add command to send a request with gz topic

summary.raw:
This pull request adds a new command to gz topic to send requests.

Its prototype is: `gz topic -r <request_name>  [-m <message>] [-f <file>]`

Optional data can be sent with options -m or -f where message is a message to send and file is the path to a file containing the message to send.

Some command line examples:

    $ gz topic -r atmosphere_info
    
    type: ADIABATIC
    temperature: 288.15
    pressure: 101325
    mass_density: 1.2249782197913108
    enable_atmosphere: true
    
    $ gz topic -r entity_delete -m ground_plane
    $ gz topic -r unknown_request
    No response received

Note that this pull request also adds a timeout parameter to gazebo::transport::request whose default value is -1 to wait forever.
summary.html:
This pull request adds a new command to gz topic to send requests.

Its prototype is: gz topic -r <request_name> [-m <message>] [-f <file>]

Optional data can be sent with options -m or -f where message is a message to send and file is the path to a file containing the message to send.

Some command line examples:

$ gz topic -r atmosphere_info

type: ADIABATIC
temperature: 288.15
pressure: 101325
mass_density: 1.2249782197913108
enable_atmosphere: true

$ gz topic -r entity_delete -m ground_plane
$ gz topic -r unknown_request
No response received

Note that this pull request also adds a timeout parameter to gazebo::transport::request whose default value is -1 to wait forever.

values.description: This avoids Ogre asserting because perspective projection cannot support angle higher than 180°. This case is met typically when running WideAngleCamera object, for which the default camera is just used for its viewport.
values.title: Force vertical field of view to be lower than 180 degrees

values.description:
Partial and complete occlusion of the directional light from the line of sight of the camera should now cause the lens flare to diminish and disappear. If the center of the light is blocked, no lens flare will be visible

Along the way I also fixed manipulating lights in the 3D window. The bug is closely related to a problem that was causing lens flare occlusion ray cast checks to fail. 

![lens_flare_occlusion_lossy.gif](data/bitbucket.org/repo/jgXqbo/images/798670463-lens_flare_occlusion_lossy.gif)
values.title: Support lens flare occlusion

summary.raw:
Partial and complete occlusion of the directional light from the line of sight of the camera should now cause the lens flare to diminish and disappear. If the center of the light is blocked, no lens flare will be visible

Along the way I also fixed manipulating lights in the 3D window. The bug is closely related to a problem that was causing lens flare occlusion ray cast checks to fail. 

![lens_flare_occlusion_lossy.gif](data/bitbucket.org/repo/jgXqbo/images/798670463-lens_flare_occlusion_lossy.gif)
summary.html:
Partial and complete occlusion of the directional light from the line of sight of the camera should now cause the lens flare to diminish and disappear. If the center of the light is blocked, no lens flare will be visible

Along the way I also fixed manipulating lights in the 3D window. The bug is closely related to a problem that was causing lens flare occlusion ray cast checks to fail.

values.description:
Ported the Screen Space Ambient Occlusion (SSAO) effect from OGRE to a visual plugin. It's a popular technique used in games to approximate ambient lighting. 

There're actually a few SSAO methods in OGRE to choose from (see [PDF](https://www.cg.tuwien.ac.at/research/publications/2010/WALLNER-2010-CSSAO/WALLNER-2010-CSSAO-doc.pdf) with description of the methods). I chose the Crease Shading method mainly for its simplicity and speed while also giving a reasonably nice looking result. Other more accurate and physically based methods are a bit more computationally expensive. 

Here's a screenshot of a scene with only white objects, no lights, max scene `<ambient>` values, and SSAO enabled (`ssao_plugin.world`), which helps to illustrate the Crease Shading effect 

![ssao_world.jpg](data/bitbucket.org/repo/jgXqbo/images/3388633340-ssao_world.jpg)

Here's `shapes.world` with shadows turned off and SSAO enabled

![shapes_ssao.jpg](data/bitbucket.org/repo/jgXqbo/images/1090205098-shapes_ssao.jpg)

I'm using this plugin to give some subtle ambient lighting effect to an interior environment.
values.title: Add Screen Space Ambient Occlusion visual plugin

summary.raw:
Ported the Screen Space Ambient Occlusion (SSAO) effect from OGRE to a visual plugin. It's a popular technique used in games to approximate ambient lighting. 

There're actually a few SSAO methods in OGRE to choose from (see [PDF](https://www.cg.tuwien.ac.at/research/publications/2010/WALLNER-2010-CSSAO/WALLNER-2010-CSSAO-doc.pdf) with description of the methods). I chose the Crease Shading method mainly for its simplicity and speed while also giving a reasonably nice looking result. Other more accurate and physically based methods are a bit more computationally expensive. 

Here's a screenshot of a scene with only white objects, no lights, max scene `<ambient>` values, and SSAO enabled (`ssao_plugin.world`), which helps to illustrate the Crease Shading effect 

![ssao_world.jpg](data/bitbucket.org/repo/jgXqbo/images/3388633340-ssao_world.jpg)

Here's `shapes.world` with shadows turned off and SSAO enabled

![shapes_ssao.jpg](data/bitbucket.org/repo/jgXqbo/images/1090205098-shapes_ssao.jpg)

I'm using this plugin to give some subtle ambient lighting effect to an interior environment.
summary.html:
Ported the Screen Space Ambient Occlusion (SSAO) effect from OGRE to a visual plugin. It's a popular technique used in games to approximate ambient lighting.

There're actually a few SSAO methods in OGRE to choose from (see PDF with description of the methods). I chose the Crease Shading method mainly for its simplicity and speed while also giving a reasonably nice looking result. Other more accurate and physically based methods are a bit more computationally expensive.

Here's a screenshot of a scene with only white objects, no lights, max scene <ambient> values, and SSAO enabled (ssao_plugin.world), which helps to illustrate the Crease Shading effect

Here's shapes.world with shadows turned off and SSAO enabled

I'm using this plugin to give some subtle ambient lighting effect to an interior environment.

values.description:
Normal maps have not been working for some time, and we have also disabled them in the gazebo models that use them, e.g. see [this line in fast_food's model.sdf](#!/osrf/gazebo_models/src/ea482a46e821ac9fe9618e469c5bf65742b42eb1/fast_food/model.sdf?fileviewer=file-view-default#model.sdf-28)

The fix only works for ubuntu with OGRE 1.9. I tried applying the same changes to the shaders in our `media/rtshaderlib` directory used by gazebo on OSX but still didn't have any luck so I disabled normal mapping on OSX for now. 

I also removed unused material scripts in the rtshader directories.

See a screenshot of the fast food model before and after applying its normal map.

Before:

![fastfood_no_normal.jpg](data/bitbucket.org/repo/jgXqbo/images/225576924-fastfood_no_normal.jpg)

After:

![fastfood_normal.jpg](data/bitbucket.org/repo/jgXqbo/images/3812733778-fastfood_normal.jpg)
values.title: Fix normal maps on ubuntu with OGRE 1.9 and disable on OSX

The fix only works for ubuntu with OGRE 1.9. I tried applying the same changes to the shaders in our `media/rtshaderlib` directory used by gazebo on OSX but still didn't have any luck so I disabled normal mapping on OSX for now. 

I also removed unused material scripts in the rtshader directories.

After:

values.description:
This adds an example plugin and world that show how to use `ContainPlugin` to trigger an action. The action in this world is turning on/off a light when a ball rolls under a lamp post.  It is intended to be referenced by [osrf/gazebo_tutorials#501](#!/osrf/gazebo_tutorials/pull-requests/501/tutorial-for-containplugin/diff).

![lamppostlight.gif](data/bitbucket.org/repo/jgXqbo/images/1125942185-lamppostlight.gif)

values.description:
Fix https://github.com/osrf/homebrew-simulation/issues/384 , by making sure that only `DARTConfig.cmake` is used for finding DART and `FindDart.cmake` is always ignored.

In theory the problem is affecting also gazebo7, but it is particularly problematic since gazebo9 because before dart was not a recommended dependency in homebrew.
values.title: Fix https://github.com/osrf/homebrew-simulation/issues/384

summary.raw:
Fix https://github.com/osrf/homebrew-simulation/issues/384 , by making sure that only `DARTConfig.cmake` is used for finding DART and `FindDart.cmake` is always ignored.

In theory the problem is affecting also gazebo7, but it is particularly problematic since gazebo9 because before dart was not a recommended dependency in homebrew.
summary.html:
Fix https://github.com/osrf/homebrew-simulation/issues/384 , by making sure that only DARTConfig.cmake is used for finding DART and FindDart.cmake is always ignored.

In theory the problem is affecting also gazebo7, but it is particularly problematic since gazebo9 because before dart was not a recommended dependency in homebrew.

values.description:
*  Changed  ModelDatabase::GetModelPath so that it operates as described in the docs to allow models to be pulled from remote servers.

Currently passing a  stl or obj by a HTTP or HTTPS request isn't caught by SystemPaths::FindFileURI(). This is a minor change to allow that request to be passed to the ModelDatabase.

Currently there is one issue - passing a package (tar.gz) will result in a blank model when it's not coming from the gazebo model database.  I've searched the code, but can't find the area that deals with searching the model tree when a new package is added. Some direction in this area would be appreciated.

Have the build running on my local machine without issues & passing tests. Happy to make any minor changes.
values.title: Allow models to be loaded from an external webserver

summary.raw:
*  Changed  ModelDatabase::GetModelPath so that it operates as described in the docs to allow models to be pulled from remote servers.

Currently passing a  stl or obj by a HTTP or HTTPS request isn't caught by SystemPaths::FindFileURI(). This is a minor change to allow that request to be passed to the ModelDatabase.

Currently there is one issue - passing a package (tar.gz) will result in a blank model when it's not coming from the gazebo model database.  I've searched the code, but can't find the area that deals with searching the model tree when a new package is added. Some direction in this area would be appreciated.

Have the build running on my local machine without issues & passing tests. Happy to make any minor changes.
summary.html:
• Changed ModelDatabase::GetModelPath so that it operates as described in the docs to allow models to be pulled from remote servers.

Currently passing a stl or obj by a HTTP or HTTPS request isn't caught by SystemPaths::FindFileURI(). This is a minor change to allow that request to be passed to the ModelDatabase.

Currently there is one issue - passing a package (tar.gz) will result in a blank model when it's not coming from the gazebo model database. I've searched the code, but can't find the area that deals with searching the model tree when a new package is added. Some direction in this area would be appreciated.

Have the build running on my local machine without issues & passing tests. Happy to make any minor changes.

values.description:
Fixes an ogre assertion error that causes gzclient to crash when moving the mouse at a distance far away from origin and with a large camera far clip distance set. The large numbers result in NaNs when generating shadows for the mouse picking selection camera. We don't actually need shadows for that camera, so disabling it fixes the problem.

To test: In gzclient, set user camera's pose x to 160,000 and far clip to 200,000. Start moving the mouse / user camera around and you may get a crash without the fix.
values.title: Fix mouse movement ogre assertion error

summary.raw:
Fixes an ogre assertion error that causes gzclient to crash when moving the mouse at a distance far away from origin and with a large camera far clip distance set. The large numbers result in NaNs when generating shadows for the mouse picking selection camera. We don't actually need shadows for that camera, so disabling it fixes the problem.

To test: In gzclient, set user camera's pose x to 160,000 and far clip to 200,000. Start moving the mouse / user camera around and you may get a crash without the fix.
summary.html:
Fixes an ogre assertion error that causes gzclient to crash when moving the mouse at a distance far away from origin and with a large camera far clip distance set. The large numbers result in NaNs when generating shadows for the mouse picking selection camera. We don't actually need shadows for that camera, so disabling it fixes the problem.

To test: In gzclient, set user camera's pose x to 160,000 and far clip to 200,000. Start moving the mouse / user camera around and you may get a crash without the fix.

values.description:
The example from pull request #2918 seems to have trouble compiling on homebrew:

* https://build.osrfoundation.org/view/os_homebrew/job/gazebo-ci-gazebo7-homebrew-amd64/225/testReport/junit/(root)/Plugins_ExamplesBuild_Plugins/Plugins_12/

~~~
497: [ 50%] Building CXX object CMakeFiles/TurnOnLightPlugin.dir/TurnOnLightPlugin.cpp.o
497: error: invalid value 'c++11 -stdlib=libc++' in '-std=c++11 -stdlib=libc++'
~~~

The example CMakeLists.txt seems to differ from the other plugins. I reverted to make it more closely match the factory plugin example. I'm open to improving the cmake code in these examples as long as it works on our supported platforms.
values.title: fix cmake for TurnOnLightPlugin example

The example CMakeLists.txt seems to differ from the other plugins. I reverted to make it more closely match the factory plugin example. I'm open to improving the cmake code in these examples as long as it works on our supported platforms.

values.description:
This is meant to fix a build issue with pull request #2918. It is an alternative to pull request #2929.

On OSX the variable `${GAZEBO_CXX_FLAGS}` was being converted to a string while adding an OSX specific option. When the flags were passed to `target_compile_options(...)` they got interpreted as a single argument instead of multiple.

This PR adds the new option without converting to a string. It should both fix the build issue with `TurnOnLightPlugin` and allow downstream OSX users to use `target_compile_options` with gazebo as well.
values.title: Fix GAZEBO_CXX_FLAGS being converted to a string on OSX

summary.raw:
This is meant to fix a build issue with pull request #2918. It is an alternative to pull request #2929.

On OSX the variable `${GAZEBO_CXX_FLAGS}` was being converted to a string while adding an OSX specific option. When the flags were passed to `target_compile_options(...)` they got interpreted as a single argument instead of multiple.

This PR adds the new option without converting to a string. It should both fix the build issue with `TurnOnLightPlugin` and allow downstream OSX users to use `target_compile_options` with gazebo as well.
summary.html:
This is meant to fix a build issue with pull request #2918. It is an alternative to pull request #2929.

On OSX the variable ${GAZEBO_CXX_FLAGS} was being converted to a string while adding an OSX specific option. When the flags were passed to target_compile_options(...) they got interpreted as a single argument instead of multiple.

This PR adds the new option without converting to a string. It should both fix the build issue with TurnOnLightPlugin and allow downstream OSX users to use target_compile_options with gazebo as well.

values.title: Add methods to set dynamically Gaussian noise parameters

summary.html:
With this commit, a camera sensor plugin can modify the mean and standard deviation of its noise distribution at runtime. For instance:

  sensors::NoisePtr noise = this->sensor->GetNoise(sensors::CAMERA_NOISE);
  if (noise)
  {
    sensors::ImageGaussianNoiseModelPtr imageGaussianNoiseModel =
      boost::dynamic_pointer_cast<sensors::ImageGaussianNoiseModel>(
          noise);

    imageGaussianNoiseModel->SetMean(0.2);
  }

values.description:
There is a problem with camera view control when the camera is inside the bounding box of a mesh. The `Scene::FirstContact` ray query intersection check will ignore that mesh, which makes it difficult to move the camera around

e.g. insert a [gazebo](http://models.gazebosim.org/gazebo/) model and move your user camera inside the model. Now try moving the camera around by dragging the mouse over any part of the gazebo mesh and you'll notice that yellow target visual does not register with the gazebo mesh.

Fixed by using the `UserCamera::GetVisual` method for finding the closest visual.
values.title: Fix camera view control inside bounding box of large meshes

summary.raw:
There is a problem with camera view control when the camera is inside the bounding box of a mesh. The `Scene::FirstContact` ray query intersection check will ignore that mesh, which makes it difficult to move the camera around

e.g. insert a [gazebo](http://models.gazebosim.org/gazebo/) model and move your user camera inside the model. Now try moving the camera around by dragging the mouse over any part of the gazebo mesh and you'll notice that yellow target visual does not register with the gazebo mesh.

Fixed by using the `UserCamera::GetVisual` method for finding the closest visual.
summary.html:
There is a problem with camera view control when the camera is inside the bounding box of a mesh. The Scene::FirstContact ray query intersection check will ignore that mesh, which makes it difficult to move the camera around

e.g. insert a gazebo model and move your user camera inside the model. Now try moving the camera around by dragging the mouse over any part of the gazebo mesh and you'll notice that yellow target visual does not register with the gazebo mesh.

Fixed by using the UserCamera::GetVisual method for finding the closest visual.

values.description: issue #2454 - the default min/max values for `ignition::math::Box` changed from `Zero` to `MAX_D`  and that broke CoM visualization.  This patch initializes the bounding box to zero.
values.title: Fix empty visual bounding box

summary.raw: issue #2454 - the default min/max values for `ignition::math::Box` changed from `Zero` to `MAX_D`  and that broke CoM visualization.  This patch initializes the bounding box to zero.
summary.html: issue #2454 - the default min/max values for ignition::math::Box changed from Zero to MAX_D and that broke CoM visualization. This patch initializes the bounding box to zero.

values.description:
While merging pull request #2928 forward to gazebo8, I noticed a compiler warning:

~~~
warning:
 ignoring return value of ‘constexpr bool qFuzzyCompare(double, double)’,
 declared with attribute warn_unused_result [-Wunused-result]
~~~

It seems that the test is not actually verifying whether the values are close, since we are not evaluating the return value of `qFuzzyCompare`. So I added `QVERIFY()` around these statements, but there was some trouble with the nearClip comparison. I think the tolerance for `qFuzzyCompare` is too strict, and the value 0.1 has some floating point truncation. To circumvent this, I changed the test value to `0.125` so it will have an exact floating point representation. I thought this was superior to the alternative recommended in the [qt docs](http://doc.qt.io/qt-5/qtglobal.html#qFuzzyCompare) of adding offset values:

~~~
QVERIFY(qFuzzyCompare(1e4 + cam->NearClip(), 1e4 + nearClip));
~~~
values.title: use QVERIFY() around qFuzzyCompare statements

summary.raw:
While merging pull request #2928 forward to gazebo8, I noticed a compiler warning:

~~~
warning:
 ignoring return value of ‘constexpr bool qFuzzyCompare(double, double)’,
 declared with attribute warn_unused_result [-Wunused-result]
~~~

It seems that the test is not actually verifying whether the values are close, since we are not evaluating the return value of `qFuzzyCompare`. So I added `QVERIFY()` around these statements, but there was some trouble with the nearClip comparison. I think the tolerance for `qFuzzyCompare` is too strict, and the value 0.1 has some floating point truncation. To circumvent this, I changed the test value to `0.125` so it will have an exact floating point representation. I thought this was superior to the alternative recommended in the [qt docs](http://doc.qt.io/qt-5/qtglobal.html#qFuzzyCompare) of adding offset values:

~~~
QVERIFY(qFuzzyCompare(1e4 + cam->NearClip(), 1e4 + nearClip));
~~~
summary.html:
While merging pull request #2928 forward to gazebo8, I noticed a compiler warning:

warning:
 ignoring return value of ‘constexpr bool qFuzzyCompare(double, double)’,
 declared with attribute warn_unused_result [-Wunused-result]

It seems that the test is not actually verifying whether the values are close, since we are not evaluating the return value of qFuzzyCompare. So I added QVERIFY() around these statements, but there was some trouble with the nearClip comparison. I think the tolerance for qFuzzyCompare is too strict, and the value 0.1 has some floating point truncation. To circumvent this, I changed the test value to 0.125 so it will have an exact floating point representation. I thought this was superior to the alternative recommended in the qt docs of adding offset values:

QVERIFY(qFuzzyCompare(1e4 + cam->NearClip(), 1e4 + nearClip));

values.description:
boost 1.67 was recently released on homebrew, and I've been working on building new gazebo bottles. There are some compilation problems:

~~~
gazebo/common/Console.cc:197:12:
 error: invalid operands to binary expression ('boost::system::error_code' and 'int')
    if (ec == 0)
        ~~ ^  ~
1 error generated.
~~~

~~~
gazebo/transport/Connection.cc:951:14:
 error: invalid operands to binary expression ('const boost::system::error_code' and 'int')
  if (_error == 0)
      ~~~~~~ ^  ~
1 error generated.
~~~

I will add this patch to the homebrew formulae for now and remove it the patch is included in the next gazebo releases.
values.title: fix compilation with boost 1.67

~~~

~~~

1 error generated.
~~~

values.description:
Identical to https://bitbucket.org/ignitionrobotics/ign-common/pull-requests/119/fix-build-on-homebrew-with-ffmpeg4/diff

Just when we had recovered from boost 1.67, ffmpeg4 has removed some macros. It's an easy fix though.

* [![Build Status](https://build.osrfoundation.org/buildStatus/icon?job=ignition_common-ci-ign-common1-homebrew-amd64&build=9)](https://build.osrfoundation.org/job/ignition_common-ci-ign-common1-homebrew-amd64/9/) ignition_common-ci-ign-common1-homebrew-amd64/9/

There are some new deprecation warnings though for the `avcodec_register_all` function, though I'm not sure what the recommended replacement is. I haven't addressed them.

* https://github.com/FFmpeg/FFmpeg/commit/7e8eba2d8755962d9dca5eade57bf8f591a73c0c
values.title: fix build on homebrew with ffmpeg4

values.description: The result of ray triangle intersection check in `Scene::FirstContact` function was never checked so false positive intersection results were produced if the ray passes the early bounding box intersection test.
values.title: Fix ray intersection check in Scene::FirstContact

values.description:
This makes the insert widget a bit more organized. Also added the full model URL as a tooltip.

![fuelbyowner.gif](data/bitbucket.org/repo/jgXqbo/images/238376683-fuelbyowner.gif)

There's still a lot of room for improvement; we need a plan for once we start having thousands of users uploading thousands of models... It would also be nice to always list `openrobotics` on top. In any case, the whole insert menu needs a makeover so it's more pleasant to browse through models.

This is broken off branch `fuel_cache`.

Remember to install `fuel-tools` and set the env var

`export USE_IGNITION_FUEL=true; gazebo --verbose`

Don't be worried about ABI, `FuelModelDatabase` is not installed.
values.title: Fuel: List models by owner on insert menu

summary.html:
This makes the insert widget a bit more organized. Also added the full model URL as a tooltip.

There's still a lot of room for improvement; we need a plan for once we start having thousands of users uploading thousands of models... It would also be nice to always list openrobotics on top. In any case, the whole insert menu needs a makeover so it's more pleasant to browse through models.

This is broken off branch fuel_cache.

Remember to install fuel-tools and set the env var

export USE_IGNITION_FUEL=true; gazebo --verbose

Don't be worried about ABI, FuelModelDatabase is not installed.

values.description:
This adds a new plugin for tuning the amount of wheel slip experienced by a wheeled robot. It dynamically adjusts the ODE `slip1` and `slip2` parameters (see Force-dependent slip parameters in [ODE user guide](http://ode.org/ode-latest-userguide.html#sec_7_3_7)). This parameter has units like an inverse damper (velocity / effort). It is often preferred to use normalized parameters, so this plugin accepts unitless `longitudinal_slip_compliance` and `lateral_slip_compliance` parameters. The `slip1` and `slip2` parameters are then dynamically updated by multiplying the normalized slip compliance by the linear wheel spin velocity (radius * angular spin rate) and dividing by a `wheel_normal_force` parameter supplied to the plugin.

Here's some ASCII art and documentation pasted from the plugin header file:

A graphical interpretation of these parameters is provided below
for a positive value of slip compliance.
The horizontal axis corresponds to the slip ratio at the wheel,
and the vertical axis corresponds to the tangential force ratio
(tangential / normal force).
As wheel slip increases, the tangential force increases until
it reaches the maximum set by the friction coefficient.
The slip compliance corresponds to the inverse of the slope
of the force before it reaches the maximum value.
A slip compliance of 0 corresponds to a completely vertical
portion of the plot below.
As slip compliance increases, the slope decreases.


~~~
+        |                                            .
+        |      _________ friction coefficient        .
+        |     /                                      .
+        |    /|                                      .
+        |   /-┘ slope is inverse of                  .
+        |  /    slip compliance                      .
+        | /                                          .
+        |/                                           .
+      --+-------------------------- slipRatio
+        |
~~~

I've added two different tests for this plugin:

* a wheel on a test rig rolling on a spinning drum (`tire_drum_test.world`)
* a bunch of variations of a `triball` models (ie. 3 connected spheres) on a ground plane with an inclined gravity vector to simulate a slope. This is a demonstration that wheeled robots seemingly at rest on a slope were drifting slowly down the slope when simulated with ODE. This test has 4 variations of the triball:
    * lumped: one lumped rigid body with 3 spherical collisions
    * fixed: one chassis and 3 spherical rigid bodies connected to chassis with fixed joints
    * revolute: like fixed but with revolute joints and joint friction
    * wheel_slip: like revolute but with the `WheelSlipPlugin` acting on each sphere.

![triball.png](data/bitbucket.org/repo/jgXqbo/images/2960193225-triball.png)

If you open the triball world interactively, it will look like they are sitting still, but if you look at the test expectations there are subtle differences (for example velocity magnitude `10^-4` vs `10^-7`) that accumulate over time.

There is also a `gazebo_ros_wheel_slip` plugin that builds on top of this one. After I submit a pull request for that plugin, I will create a tutorial for how to use it.
values.title: Adding WheelSlipPlugin: for adding wheel slip using ODE's contact parameters

summary.raw:
This adds a new plugin for tuning the amount of wheel slip experienced by a wheeled robot. It dynamically adjusts the ODE `slip1` and `slip2` parameters (see Force-dependent slip parameters in [ODE user guide](http://ode.org/ode-latest-userguide.html#sec_7_3_7)). This parameter has units like an inverse damper (velocity / effort). It is often preferred to use normalized parameters, so this plugin accepts unitless `longitudinal_slip_compliance` and `lateral_slip_compliance` parameters. The `slip1` and `slip2` parameters are then dynamically updated by multiplying the normalized slip compliance by the linear wheel spin velocity (radius * angular spin rate) and dividing by a `wheel_normal_force` parameter supplied to the plugin.

Here's some ASCII art and documentation pasted from the plugin header file:

A graphical interpretation of these parameters is provided below
for a positive value of slip compliance.
The horizontal axis corresponds to the slip ratio at the wheel,
and the vertical axis corresponds to the tangential force ratio
(tangential / normal force).
As wheel slip increases, the tangential force increases until
it reaches the maximum set by the friction coefficient.
The slip compliance corresponds to the inverse of the slope
of the force before it reaches the maximum value.
A slip compliance of 0 corresponds to a completely vertical
portion of the plot below.
As slip compliance increases, the slope decreases.


~~~
+        |                                            .
+        |      _________ friction coefficient        .
+        |     /                                      .
+        |    /|                                      .
+        |   /-┘ slope is inverse of                  .
+        |  /    slip compliance                      .
+        | /                                          .
+        |/                                           .
+      --+-------------------------- slipRatio
+        |
~~~

I've added two different tests for this plugin:

* a wheel on a test rig rolling on a spinning drum (`tire_drum_test.world`)
* a bunch of variations of a `triball` models (ie. 3 connected spheres) on a ground plane with an inclined gravity vector to simulate a slope. This is a demonstration that wheeled robots seemingly at rest on a slope were drifting slowly down the slope when simulated with ODE. This test has 4 variations of the triball:
    * lumped: one lumped rigid body with 3 spherical collisions
    * fixed: one chassis and 3 spherical rigid bodies connected to chassis with fixed joints
    * revolute: like fixed but with revolute joints and joint friction
    * wheel_slip: like revolute but with the `WheelSlipPlugin` acting on each sphere.

![triball.png](data/bitbucket.org/repo/jgXqbo/images/2960193225-triball.png)

If you open the triball world interactively, it will look like they are sitting still, but if you look at the test expectations there are subtle differences (for example velocity magnitude `10^-4` vs `10^-7`) that accumulate over time.

There is also a `gazebo_ros_wheel_slip` plugin that builds on top of this one. After I submit a pull request for that plugin, I will create a tutorial for how to use it.
summary.html:
This adds a new plugin for tuning the amount of wheel slip experienced by a wheeled robot. It dynamically adjusts the ODE slip1 and slip2 parameters (see Force-dependent slip parameters in ODE user guide). This parameter has units like an inverse damper (velocity / effort). It is often preferred to use normalized parameters, so this plugin accepts unitless longitudinal_slip_compliance and lateral_slip_compliance parameters. The slip1 and slip2 parameters are then dynamically updated by multiplying the normalized slip compliance by the linear wheel spin velocity (radius * angular spin rate) and dividing by a wheel_normal_force parameter supplied to the plugin.

Here's some ASCII art and documentation pasted from the plugin header file:

A graphical interpretation of these parameters is provided below for a positive value of slip compliance. The horizontal axis corresponds to the slip ratio at the wheel, and the vertical axis corresponds to the tangential force ratio (tangential / normal force). As wheel slip increases, the tangential force increases until it reaches the maximum set by the friction coefficient. The slip compliance corresponds to the inverse of the slope of the force before it reaches the maximum value. A slip compliance of 0 corresponds to a completely vertical portion of the plot below. As slip compliance increases, the slope decreases.

+        |                                            .
+        |      _________ friction coefficient        .
+        |     /                                      .
+        |    /|                                      .
+        |   /-┘ slope is inverse of                  .
+        |  /    slip compliance                      .
+        | /                                          .
+        |/                                           .
+      --+-------------------------- slipRatio
+        |

I've added two different tests for this plugin:

  • a wheel on a test rig rolling on a spinning drum (tire_drum_test.world)
  • a bunch of variations of a triball models (ie. 3 connected spheres) on a ground plane with an inclined gravity vector to simulate a slope. This is a demonstration that wheeled robots seemingly at rest on a slope were drifting slowly down the slope when simulated with ODE. This test has 4 variations of the triball:
    • lumped: one lumped rigid body with 3 spherical collisions
    • fixed: one chassis and 3 spherical rigid bodies connected to chassis with fixed joints
    • revolute: like fixed but with revolute joints and joint friction
    • wheel_slip: like revolute but with the WheelSlipPlugin acting on each sphere.

If you open the triball world interactively, it will look like they are sitting still, but if you look at the test expectations there are subtle differences (for example velocity magnitude 10^-4 vs 10^-7) that accumulate over time.

There is also a gazebo_ros_wheel_slip plugin that builds on top of this one. After I submit a pull request for that plugin, I will create a tutorial for how to use it.

values.description:
This pull request adds a new command to `gz topic` to publish messages on a topic. It is quite similar to `gz topic -r` but works for general topics instead of `~/request`.

Its prototype is: `gz topic -p <topic_name> [-m <message>] [-f <file>]`

Optional data can be sent with options `-m <message>` or `-f <file>` where message is a message to send and file is the path to a file containing the message to send.

Some command line examples:

To modify the temperature:

    $ gz topic -p /gazebo/default/atmosphere -m temperature:300

The following works as well:

    $ gz topic -p "~/atmosphere" -m temperature:300

To undo the last command:

    $ gz topic -p /gazebo/default/undo_redo -m undo:true

To stop the server:

    $ gz topic -p /gazebo/server/control -m stop:true
values.title: Add command to send messages on a topic with gz

summary.raw:
This pull request adds a new command to `gz topic` to publish messages on a topic. It is quite similar to `gz topic -r` but works for general topics instead of `~/request`.

Its prototype is: `gz topic -p <topic_name> [-m <message>] [-f <file>]`

Optional data can be sent with options `-m <message>` or `-f <file>` where message is a message to send and file is the path to a file containing the message to send.

Some command line examples:

To modify the temperature:

    $ gz topic -p /gazebo/default/atmosphere -m temperature:300

The following works as well:

To undo the last command:

To stop the server:

    $ gz topic -p /gazebo/server/control -m stop:true
summary.html:
This pull request adds a new command to gz topic to publish messages on a topic. It is quite similar to gz topic -r but works for general topics instead of ~/request.

Its prototype is: gz topic -p <topic_name> [-m <message>] [-f <file>]

Optional data can be sent with options -m <message> or -f <file> where message is a message to send and file is the path to a file containing the message to send.

Some command line examples:

To modify the temperature:

$ gz topic -p /gazebo/default/atmosphere -m temperature:300

The following works as well:

$ gz topic -p "~/atmosphere" -m temperature:300

To undo the last command:

$ gz topic -p /gazebo/default/undo_redo -m undo:true

To stop the server:

$ gz topic -p /gazebo/server/control -m stop:true
